post.description:
Redact a customer to remove all collected information from Falu.
This will redact the Customer and all objects related to it,
including Events, request logs, etc.

The redaction process may take up a week. When the redaction process is in progress,
the Customer's `redaction.status` field will be set to `processing`;
when the process is finished, it will change to `redacted` and a
`customer.redacted` event will be emitted.

Redaction is irreversible. Redacted objects are still accessible in the API,
but all the fields that contain personal data will be replaced by the string
`[redacted]` or a similar placeholder. The metadata field will also be erased.
Redacted objects cannot be updated or used for any purpose.

post.description:
A subscription can be cancelled when it is in `active` or `in_trial` status.
Once cancelled, future submission attempts are disabled. This cannot be undone. A final
invoice will be generated for any un-invoiced metered usage and new/pending proration invoice items.
[Learn more.](/subscriptions#cancel)

post.description:
Redact an event to remove all collected information from Falu.
This will redact the Event its webhooks

Redacting an event is also done when related objects such as identity verifications are redacted.
As such, you do not need to redact each event created in the process.
Redacting an event is useful if the object that created it no longer exists.

Redacting an event is instant and does not emit any other event. Redacted events cannot be delivered.

Redaction is irreversible. Redacted objects are still accessible in the API,
but all the fields that contain personal data will be replaced by the string
`[redacted]` or a similar placeholder. The metadata field will also be erased.
Redacted objects cannot be updated or used for any purpose.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of the event

post.summary: Redact the contents of a file.
post.description:
Redact a file to remove all collected information from Falu.
This will redact the File and all objects related to it,
including Events, request logs, etc.

Redacting a file is also done when related objects such as identity verifications are redacted.
As such, you do not need to redact each file created in the process.
Redacting a file is useful if you uploaded a file that you have not used and have
no intention of doing so, such as one that was uploaded by mistake.

When the redaction process completes a `file.redacted` event will be emitted.

Redaction is irreversible. Redacted objects are still accessible in the API,
but all the fields that contain personal data will be replaced by the string
`[redacted]` or a similar placeholder. The metadata field will also be erased.
Redacted objects cannot be updated or used for any purpose.

post.description:
An identity verification can be cancelled when it is in `input_required` status.
Once cancelled, future submission attempts are disabled. This cannot be undone.
[Learn more.](/identity/verifications#cancel)

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier for the identity verification

post.description:
Redact an identity verification to remove all collected information from Falu.
This will redact the IdentityVerification and all objects related to it,
including IdentityVerificationReports, Events, request logs, etc.
An identity verification can be redacted when it is in `input_required` or `verified` status.
Redacting an identity verification in `input_required` state will automatically cancel it.

The redaction process may take up a week. When the redaction process is in progress,
the IdentityVerification's `redaction.status` field will be set to `processing`;
when the process is finished, it will change to `redacted` and an
`identity_verification.redacted` event will be emitted.

Redaction is irreversible. Redacted objects are still accessible in the API,
but all the fields that contain personal data will be replaced by the string
`[redacted]` or a similar placeholder. The metadata field will also be erased.
Redacted objects cannot be updated or used for any purpose.

a `X-Continuation-Token` header with value `bravo`, your subsequent
call can include `ct=bravo`.

Represents a credit or debit adjustment against a customer's balance. This is the only
type of transaction that can be created via the API or dashboard. It can also be created
as a result of prorations and thus can be applied to future invoices.
x-enumDescriptions.credit_note: Traces creation of credit to a credit note and it's associated invoice.
x-enumDescriptions.applied_to_invoice: Traces application of credit against a linked invoice.
x-enumDescriptions.invoice_too_small:
When the amount due on an invoice is smaller than the minimum chargeable amount the invoice
is debited to the customer balance and added to the amount due of the next issued invoice.
x-enumDescriptions.invoice_too_large:
When the amount due on an invoice is greater than the maximum chargeable amount the invoice
is debited to the customer balance and added to the amount due of the next issued invoice.
x-enumDescriptions.unapplied_from_invoice:
Traces the reversal of an applied customer balance from a linked invoice.
Paired with an earlier applied_to_invoice transaction.

status.description:

[Learn more about the lifecycle of verifications](/identity/how-verifications-work).

to be performed.

return_url.description: The URL the user will be redirected to upon completing the verification flow.

client_secret.description:
The short-lived client secret used by front-end libraries to show a verification modal inside your app.
This client secret expires after 24 hours and can only be used once.
Dont store it, log it, embed it in a URL, or expose it to anyone other than the user.
Make sure that you have TLS enabled on any page that includes the client secret.
Refer to our docs on
[passing the client secret to the frontend](/identity/verifications#client-secret)
to learn more.

url.description:
The short-lived URL that you use to redirect a user to Falu to submit their identity information.
This link expires after 24 hours and can only be used once.
Dont store it, log it, send it in emails or expose it to anyone other than the target user.


Refer to the
[verifying identity documents](/identity/verify-documents?platform=web&type=redirect)
guide to learn how to redirect users to Falu.

countries.description:
The allowed countries specified as the three-letter
[ISO country code](https://www.iso.org/iso-3166-country-codes.html), in lowercase.
If a user selects or uploads a document from a country which isn't one of the allowed ones, it will be rejected.
When not provided, all countries are allowed.

allow_uploads.description:
Whether to allow uploads for documents, images and videos.
This only applies to document related checks.
To enhance security and improved the overall user experience,
uploads are disabled by default. Set this to
true to allow uploading files.

max_attempts.description:
The maximum number of verification attempts the user is allowed to make. A large number of attempts
could signal fraudulent behavior.

allowed.description:

If a user provides an identity tax id type which isn't one of the allowed types, it will be rejected.

default_payment_method.description:
Identifier of the default payment method that's attached to the customer associated with the invoice,
to be used as the default payment method for invoice.
If none is set, the customer's default payment method us used.

description.description:
An optional arbitrary string attached to the object.
Mainly used to describe the object and often useful for displaying to users.

metadata.description:
Set of key-value pairs that you can attach to an object. This can be useful
for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.
The key can only contain alphanumeric, and -, _ characters,
and the string has to start with a letter.

created.description: Time at which the object was created.

updated.description: Time at which the object was last updated.

customer.description: Identifier of the customer this invoice belongs to.

customer_details.description:
Invoiced customer details.
This information is pulled from the customer at the
point of invoice creation and cannot be changed afterwards.

subscription.description: Identifier of the subscription this invoice was prepared for, if any.

number.description:
A uniquely identifying string that appears on communications sent to the customer for this invoice.
This is prefixed by a global workspace prefix or per customer, if specified.

period.description: Usage period during which invoice items were added to this invoice.

items.description:
The individual items that make up the invoice.
They are sorted as follows:
- (1) pending invoice items (including prorations) in reverse chronological order,
- (2) subscription items in reverse chronological order, and
- (3) invoice items added after invoice creation in chronological order.

subtotal.description:
Total of all subscriptions, invoice items, and prorations on the invoice before any invoice level discount or tax is applied.
Item discounts are already incorporated.

tax.description: The amount of tax on this invoice. This is the sum of all the tax amounts on this invoice.

total.description: Total amount (in the smallest unit of the specified `currency`) of the invoice.

balance_brought_forward.description:
Starting customer balance before the invoice is finalized.
If the invoice has not been finalized yet, this will be the current customer balance.

balance_resulting.description: The customer balance after the invoice has been finalized.

amount_due.description:
Final amount due at this time for this invoice.
If the invoices total is smaller than the minimum payment amount, for example,
or if there is account credit that can be applied to the invoice, this value may be 0.
If there is a positive `starting_balance` for the invoice (the customer owes money),
this value will also take that into account.
The payment that gets generated for the invoice will be for the value specified here.

amount_paid.description: Amount (in the smallest unit of the specified `currency`) that was paid.

amount_remaining.description:
The difference between `amount_due` and `amount_paid`,
in the smallest unit of the specified `currency`.

paid.description:
Whether a payment was successfully collected for the invoice.
A successful payment can come via credit or a charge via a payment method.

paid_externally.description:
Boolean representing if a payment was settled outside Falu.
Returns true if the payment has been manually marked as paid,
returns false if the invoice hasn't been paid yet or was paid in Falu.

default_tax_rates.description: The tax rates that applied to this invoice for invoice items that does not have rax rates set.

total_discount_amounts.description: The aggregate amounts calculated per discount across all line items.

total_tax_amounts.description: The aggregate amounts calculated per tax rate for all invoice items.

pdf_url.description:
The link to download the PDF for the invoice.
Only available after the invoice has been finalized.

attempts.description:
Details about attempts for the invoice.
Only available after the invoice has been finalized.

workspace.description: Unique identifier for the workspace that the object belongs to.

live.description: Indicates if this object belongs in the live environment

etag.description:
A value that validates concurrent access of this object when stored in the database.
This value changes with every update and can thus be used to track changes.

count.description:
Number of payment attempts made for this invoice, from the perspective of the payment retry schedule.
Any payment attempt counts as the first attempt, and subsequently only automatic retries increment this value.
In other words, manual payment attempts after the first attempt do not affect the retry schedule.

next.description:
The time at which payment will next be attempted.
This value will be `null` for invoices where collection is manual or there is no further attempt.

previous.description: Timestamps for all previous payment attempts of this invoice.

name.description: The customers full name or business name.

An optional arbitrary string attached to the object.
Mainly used to describe the object and often useful for displaying to users.

and the string has to start with a letter.

created.description: Time at which the object was created.

updated.description: Time at which the object was last updated.

customer.description: Identifier of the customer this invoice item belongs to.

invoice.description: Identifier of the invoice this invoice item belongs to.

price.description: Identifier of the price for the invoice item.

subscription.description: Identifier of the subscription that this invoice item has been created for, if any.

subscription_item.description: Identifier of the subscription item that this invoice item has been created for, if any.

period.description:
The period associated with this invoice item.
When set to different values, the period will be rendered on the invoice.

quantity.description:
Quantity of units for the invoice item.
If the invoice item is a proration, the quantity of the subscription that the proration was computed for.

unit_amount.description:
Amount (in the smallest unit of the specified `currency`) for each unit of the invoice item.
This will be multiplied by the quantity to get the total.

amount.description:
Amount (in the smallest unit of the specified `currency`) of the invoice item.
This should always be equal to `unit_amount` * `quantity`.

proration.description: Whether the invoice item was created automatically as a proration adjustment when the customer switched plans.

discount_amounts.description: The amount of discount calculated per discount for this invoice item.

tax_rates.description:
The tax rates which apply to the invoice item.
When set, the default tax rates on the invoice do not apply to this invoice item.

tax_amounts.description: The amount of tax calculated per tax rate for this invoice item.

messages.description:

You can send up to 1,000 messages in one API request.

stream.description:
The stream to use.
It can either be the name or unique identifier of the stream.

from.description:
The sender that sends these messages.
It can be a short code, alphanumeric sender value or unique identifier of the sender.
When not provided, Falu will use the most appropriate or first available sender in your stream.

schedule.description:
Schedule for sending the messages.
When not provided or set to `null`, the message(s)
is/are enqueued for immediate sending.

x-enumDescriptions.rcs:
Rich Communication Services (RCS)
powered by [Google](https://businessmessages.google/),
and as described
[here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rich_Communication_Services).

metadata.description:
Set of key-value pairs that you can attach to an object. This can be useful
for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.
The key can only contain alphanumeric, and -, _ characters,
and the string has to start with a letter.

body.description:
Actual message content to be sent.
Required if `template` is not specified.

template.description:
The template to use.
Required if `body` is not specified.

media.description: Media to be sent with the message.

stream.description:
The stream to use.
It can either be the name or unique identifier of the stream.

from.description:
The sender that sends this message.
It can be a short code, alphanumeric sender value or unique identifier of the sender.
When not provided, Falu will use the most appropriate or first available sender in your stream.

schedule.description:
Schedule for sending the message.
When not provided or set to `null`, the message
is/are enqueued for immediate sending.

url.description:
Publicly accessible URL for the media file.
Required if `file` is not specified.

file.description:
Unique identifier of the file containing the media file.
Required if `url` is not specified.

time.description:
Time at which the message(s) should be sent.
Between 5 minutes and 30 days in the future.
Required if `delay` is not specified.

delay.description:
The [ISO 8601 duration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations)
for which the message(s) should be delayed before sending, relative to the current server time.
Between 5 minutes and 30 days.
Required if `time` is not specified.

language.description:
Three-letter [ISO language code](https://www.iso.org/iso-639-language-codes.html),
in lowercase.

This determines the language translation to be used.
When not provided, the default one is used.

model.description: Model applied when rendering the template.

code.description: A short machine-readable string giving the reason for the failure.

timestamp.description: Time at which failure occurred, if any.

description.description:
A human-readable message giving the reason for the failure.
This message can be shown to your user.
description.example: Declined due to limit rule: less than the minimum transaction amount.

url.description:
Publicly accessible URL for the media file.
Present if `file` is not specified.

file.description:
Unique identifier of the file containing the media file.
Present if `url` is not specified.

size.description: Size in bytes of the media.

time.description: Time at which the message is/was scheduled to be sent.

delay.description:

for which the message is/was to be delayed before sending.

code.description:
The numeric code managed.
This value is not shown to the recipient.
Instead, they see the `sender` value.


You can share it with your customers for them to send you messages.

sender.description:
The alphanumeric code for sending messages.
This value is shown to the recipient but they cannot reply.
Instead, use `code` or a different sender to receive messages.

alphanumeric.description:

This value cannot contain only numbers.
Required if the sender type is `alphanumeric`.

number.description:
The phone number managed in
[E.164 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E.164).
You can use this number to receive messages.

code.description:
The numeric code managed.
This value is shown to the recipient and they can reply.
You can share it with your customers for them to send you messages.

x-enumDescriptions.alphanumeric:
A branded sender identifier that can be used for sending messages.
Its value is shown to the recipient but they cannot reply.
Instead, use the managed `short_code` in the sender to receive messages.

tiering_mode.description:
Determines how the tiering behaviour is applied on the quantity.
In `volume`-based tiering, the maximum quantity within a period determines the per unit price,
whereas in `graduated` tiering pricing can successively change as the quantity grows.
When set to `none`, `unit_amount` must be provided,
otherwise at least one element in `tiers` must be provided.
Defaults to `none`.

Required when `tiering_mode` is not set to `none`

x-enumDescriptions.sum: Sum up all usage during the billing period.
x-enumDescriptions.max: Use the usage record with the maximum value during the billing period.
x-enumDescriptions.last: Use the last reported value within the billing period.

x-enumDescriptions.seats: Bills the quantity set when adding/updating the subscription item or it subscription.
x-enumDescriptions.usage_units: Aggregates the usage based on reported usage records.

metering_type.description:
How the quantity per period should be billed.
`seats` bills the quantity set when adding/updating the subscription item whereas
`usage_units` aggregates based on usage records.
Defaults to `seats`.

metering_aggregation.description:
How the usage records should be aggregated for seats with `metering_type=usage_units`.
Defaults to `sum`.

breakpoint.description:
Value up to and including which the quantity will be container in the tier.
Setting `null` is only allowed for one tier in the list of tiers.

flat_amount.description: Price for the entire tier, regardless of the number of units in the tier.

unit_amount.description: Per unit price for each individual unit for which this tier applies.

x-enumDescriptions.none: A fixed per-unit price is used to charge for each quantity.
x-enumDescriptions.volume: The maximum quantity within a period determines the per-unit price.
x-enumDescriptions.graduated: Pricing can successively change as the quantity changes.

for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.

and the string has to start with a letter.

prorate.description:
Whether to generate a proration invoice item that credits remaining unused time until the subscription period end.
Must be provided, and is only applicable, when the subscription item's metering_type is seats.

invoice_now.description:
Whether to generate an invoice if there are any prorations done.
Must be provided, and is only applicable, when the subscription item's metering_type is seats and prorate is set to true.
When set to true, an invoice will be generated and we'll attempt to charge the customer. If charging fails, the subscription will
transition to past_due state.
When set to false, a prorated invoice item will be created and will be part of the next invoice generated at the start of the next
billing period.

action.description:

Use `decrement` to subtract the specified quantity to the usage at the specified timestamp.
Use `set` to overwrite the usage quantity at the specified timestamp.

`set` is not allowed for subscriptions with
[billing thresholds](/api-reference/subscriptions/object#subscription_object-thresholds).

and the string has to start with a letter.

TransferReversalUpdateOptions.description: Represents the details that can be patched in a transfer reversal.

TransferType.description: The medium used for the transfer.

An optional arbitrary string attached to the object.
Mainly used to describe the object and often useful for displaying to users.

date.description: Time at which the user gave consent.

ip.description: IP address from which the user gave consent.

user_agent.description: User agent of the device (e.g. browser) from which the user gave consent.
user_agent.example: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/97.0.4692.71 Safari/537.36

UserConsent.description: Represents details about user content for a process or anything really.

type.description: A URI reference [RFC3986] that identifies the problem type. This specification encourages that, when dereferenced, it provide human-readable documentation for the problem type (e.g., using HTML [W3C.REC-html5-20141028]). When this member is not present, its value is assumed to be "about:blank".

title.description: A short, human-readable summary of the problem type.It SHOULD NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the problem, except for purposes of localization (e.g., using proactive content negotiation; see [RFC9110], Section 3.4).

status.description: The HTTP status code ([RFC9110], Section 6) generated by the origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.

instance.description: A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem.It may or may not yield further information if dereferenced.

errors.description: The validation errors associated with this instance.

traceId.description: An identifier to correlate the request between the client and the server

url.description: The documentation URL containing more information about the error.

created.description: Time at which the object was created.

updated.description: Time at which the object was last updated.

type.description: Type of the event (e.g. money_provider.balance.updated, message.delivered, etc.).

next.description: Next attempt scheduled for this webhook, if any.

redaction.description:
Redaction information of this object.
If the object is not redacted, this field will be null.

workspace.description: Unique identifier for the workspace that the object belongs to.

live.description: Indicates if this object belongs in the live environment

etag.description:
A value that validates concurrent access of this object when stored in the database.
This value changes with every update and can thus be used to track changes.

manual.description: Indicates if this attempt was automatic or manually triggered via dashboard or CLI.

url.description: The URL to which the delivery was made.

attempted.description: Time at which the attempt was made.

request.description: The raw request body sent for this delivery to the `url`.

code.description: The Status Code returned in the HTTP request delivery for this attempt

time.description: The amount of time taken to receive the response in milliseconds

successful.description: The status of the delivery attempt.

events.description: The list of events this endpoint accepts.

scheduled.description: Time at which the attempt is scheduled to be made.

object.description:
Object containing the API resource relevant to the event.
For example, a `money_provider.balance.updated` event will have a full payment balances object.

previous.description:
Object containing the names of the properties that have changed, and their previous
values (sent along only with `*.updated` events).

request.description: Information on the API request that instigated the event.

400.description: The request is invalid, see response for more details.

X-Falu-Signature.name: X-Falu-Signature
X-Falu-Signature.description: A signature used to check the integrity of the webhook event request. See [docs](/developers/webhooks/signatures) for more information.

X-Continuation-Token.description:
A value used to determine the starting point of a subsequent request. This value is present if there is more data that to be pulled.
If you include this value in a subsequent request, be sure to pass the original URI on the request. For example, if you have specified a filter or `count` option as part of the original request, you will want to include that option on subsequent requests. Otherwise your subsequent requests may return unexpected results.

X-Request-Id.description: Used to uniquely identify the HTTP request in logs.

X-Trace-Id.description: Used to uniquely identify the HTTP request. This ID is used to correlate the HTTP request between a client and server.

basicAuth.description: Basic HTTP authentication. Expected header format: `Authorization: Basic <api_key>` or `Authorization: Basic base64('<api_key>:')`

bearerAuth.description: Bearer HTTP authentication. Expected header format: `Authorization: Bearer <api_key>`

post.description: Webhook notifications are based on standardized events as governed by the [Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF)](https://cncf.io/).For more information see the [Cloud Events website](https://cloudevents.io/) and the [official spec](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec)

200.description: Your server implementation should return this HTTP status code if the data was received successfully

400.description: Your server implementation should return the 4xx range of HTTP status codes to indicate it does not understand the format of the payload. The delivery will be treated as a failure and no retries are attempted.

500.description: Your server implementation should return the 5xx range of HTTP status codes to indicate a server-side error. The delivery will be treated as a failure retries shall be attempted.

tags.name: Coupons
tags.description:
A coupon contains information about a percent-off or amount-off discount you might want to apply for your customers.
They may be applied to [Subscriptions](#billing/subscriptions), [Invoices](#billing/invoices), and more.
However, they do not work with one-off transactions such as [Payments](#money/payments) and [Transfers](#money/transfers).

tags.name: Credit Notes
tags.description: Credit notes are used to adjust an invoice's amount after the invoice is finalized (not in draft mode).

tags.name: Customer Balance Transactions
tags.description:
This object represents the balance transactions related to a Customer(#billing/customers). These balances can be used to
issue credit or debit adjustments. Adjustments in the credit balance could be a credit (meaning you owe them money)
or a debit (meaning they owe you money). The adjustments can then apply to future [Invoices](#billing/invoices).

tags.name: Customer Tax Ids
tags.description: This object represents the tax ids related to a Customer(#billing/customers).

tags.name: Customers
tags.description:
This object represents a customer of your business.
It lets you track payments, transfers, subscriptions, and messages that belong to the same customer.

tags.name: Discounts
tags.description:
A discount represents the actual application of a [Coupon](#billing/coupons).
It contains information about when the discount began, when it will end, and what it is applied to.

tags.name: Events
tags.description:
Events are our way of letting you know when something interesting happens in your
workspace. When an interesting events occurs, we create a new `Event` object. For
example, when a payment succeeds, we create a `payment.succeeded` event; and when
a message delivery fails, we create an `message.failed` event. Note that many API
requests may cause multiple events to be created. For example, if you create a new
message, you will receive both a `message.sent` event and either a `message.failed`
or `message.delivered` event.

Events occur when the state of another API resource changes. The state of that resource
at the time of the change is embedded in the event's data field. For example, a
`message.sent` event will contain a message, and a `payment.failed` event will contain
a payment.

As with other API resources, you can use endpoints to retrieve an
[individual event](#events_get_event) or a [list of events](#events_get_events) from
the API. We also have a separate [webhooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webhook) API
for sending the `Event` objects directly to an endpoint on your server. Webhooks are
managed in your [workspace](https://dashboard.falu.io/webhooks), and our
[Using Webhooks](/developers/webhooks) guide will help you get setup.

**NOTE:** Access to events through the [Retrieve Event API](#events_get_event)
is guaranteed only for the last 30 days.

tags.name: File Links
tags.description:
To share the contents of an `File` object with non-Falu users, you can create an `FileLink`.
It contains a URL that can be used to retrieve the contents of the file without authentication.

tags.name: Files
tags.description:
This is an object representing a file hosted on Falu's servers.
The file may have been uploaded by yourself using the [create file](#files_post_file)
request (for example, when uploading an identity document) or it may have been created by Falu
(for example, a statement of accounts).

tags.name: Identity Verification Reports
tags.description:
An `IdentityVerificationReport` is the result of an attempt to collect and verify data from a user.
You can find the result of each verification check performed in the appropriate node: `document`, `id_number`, `tax_number`.

Each `IdentityVerificationReport` contains a copy of any data collected by the user as well as reference identifiers
which can be used to access collected images.
IdentityVerificationReports are created automatically via the [IdentityVerification API](#identity_identity_verifications).

tags.name: Identity Verifications
tags.description:
An IdentityVerification guides you through the process of collecting and verifying the identities of your users.
It contains details such as what [verification check](/identity/verification-checks) to perform.
Only create one IdentityVerification for each verification in your system.

An IdentityVerification transitions through [multiple statuses](/identity/how-verifications-work) throughout
its lifetime as it progresses through the verification flow. The IdentityVerification contains the users
verified data after verification checks are complete.

tags.name: Invoice Items
tags.description: Invoice items represent the component lines of an invoice.

tags.name: Invoices
tags.description:
Invoices are statements of amounts owed by a customer, and are either generated one-off, or generated periodically from a subscription.

They contain invoice items, and proration adjustments that may be caused by subscription upgrades/downgrades (if necessary).

tags.name: Message Batches
tags.description:
To send multiple messages you create a `MessageBatch` object. You can retrieve,
cancel, redact individual messages or the message batch.

Falu supports sending messages or various types and destinations
as described in the message types [guide](/messages/types)

`MessageBatch` objects expire after 45 days alongside the `Message` objects managed
by it, after which they are forcefully purged from all our records.

tags.name: Message Senders
tags.description:
A `MessageSender` object is a representation of a resource that you use
to send messages for branding purposes.

This is usually an alphanumeric or numeric-only code that identifies
your business or its units to your customers.

tags.name: Message Streams
tags.description:
A `MessageStream` object allows you to manage the different kinds of messages
that you send or received in your workspace. You may have up to 10 streams in
your workspace, including the default ones. Default streams cannot be deleted.

`MessageStream` objects help you categorize your messages into multiple categories
and also allows us to maintain high delivery rates for transactional messages.
The messages sent via transactional streams are closely monitored to prevent abuse.

tags.name: Message Suppressions
tags.description:
A `MessageSuppression` object allows you to manage the phone number destinations
that are not currently active for sending to.

tags.name: Message Templates
tags.description:
To separate the concerns in sending messages and deciding the message content,
use a `MessageTemplate` object. In most setups, the message content is designed
and evolved by the marketing and operations teams whereas, the actual message
sending is done by the developers. Message templates help reduce the friction.

`MessageTemplate` objects can also be used to maintain messages in different
languages/regions with much less technical debt in your system.

tags.name: Messages
tags.description:
To send a message you create a `Message` object. You can retrieve and
redact individual messages as well as list messages.

Falu supports sending messages or various types and destinations
as described in the message types [guide](/messages/types)

`Message` objects can also be created if your workspace supports messages
from customers to your business. These are referred to inbound messages.

`Message` objects expire after 45 days, after which they are forcefully
purged from all our records.

tags.name: Money Balances
tags.description:
Money balances are a reflection of the money available in bring-your-own provider setups.
For fully managed ones, check the workspace balance.

tags.name: Payment Authorizations
tags.description:
When a payment provider supports customer initiated payments and a customer initiates
a payment, a Payment `Authorization` object is created.
[Authorizations](/payments/authorizations) must be approved for the payment to
be completed successfully.

externalDocs.description: Accepting a Payment with the Payment Authorizations API

tags.name: Payment Methods
tags.description:
`PaymentMethod` objects represent your customer's payment instruments.
You can use them to collect payments or attach them to customer objects to store instrument details for future payments.

tags.name: Payment Refunds
tags.description:
`PaymentRefund` object allows you to refund a payment that has been previously been
created but not yet refunded. Funds will be refunded to the payment instrument
that was originally charged. Some payment providers have a time window after which
refunds cannot happen. In this case you can initiate a `Transfer` to the
customer with the appropriate amount.

tags.name: Payments
tags.description:
To initiate a payment from a customer, you create a `Payment` object. You can retrieve
and refund individual payments as well as a list all payments.

`Payment` objects can also be created if your workspace supports payment providers that
allow customers to initiate the payments such as MPESA and EFT/RTGS. In this case, the
provider may require you to authorize the payment before it is completed. Our
[Working with Payment Authorizations](/payments/authorizations) guide will help
you get setup.

tags.name: Prices
tags.description: Prices define the unit cost, currency, and billing cycle (if any) for both recurring and one-time purchases of products.

tags.name: Products
tags.description: Subscriptions allow you to bill a customer on a recurring basis per unit, seat or based on usage.

tags.name: Subscription Items
tags.description: Subscription items allow you to create customer subscriptions with more than one plan, making it easy to represent complex billing relationships.

tags.name: Subscription Usage
tags.description: Subscription usage records allow you to report customer usage for metered billing of subscription prices.

tags.name: Subscriptions
tags.description: Subscriptions allow you to bill a customer on a recurring basis per unit, seat or based on usage.

tags.name: Tax Rates
tags.description: Tax rates can be applied to invoices and subscriptions to collect tax.

tags.name: Temporary Keys
tags.description:
A temporary key is a special kind of API key but its is valid for 1 hour from the creation time
and restricted to a specific object.

tags.name: Transfer Reversals
tags.description:
`TransferReversal` object allows you to reverse a transfer that has been previously
created but not yet reversed. Funds will be refunded your workspace.

**NOTE:** Some providers have a time windows after which reversals cannot happen.

tags.name: Transfers
tags.description:
A `Transfer` object is created when you move money from your business either to another
business or to a customer.

tags.name: Webhook Endpoints
tags.description:
You can configure [webhook endpoints](/developers/webhooks) via the API to be notified about events that happen in your Falu workspace.

Most users configure webhooks from [the dashboard](https://dashboard.falu.io/webhooks),
which provides a user interface to registering and testing your webhook endpoints.

tags.name: Webhooks
tags.description:
Every time an event is generated and there is an enabled webhook endpoint for the event type,
Falu server generate a `Webhook` which represents the delivery of the event to the given webhook.
It contains the delivery history and can be retried if failed.
